description: Dive into "Nuremberg's Picture-Perfect Discoveries" â€” a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Nuremberg's Picture-Perfect Discoveries

places.generalDescription: Landmark, restored replica of the 14th-century Beautiful Fountain, built to resemble a Gothic spire.

sources.snippet: The SchÃ¶ner Brunnen (' Beautiful Fountain') also stands on the main square near the town hall and one of the city tourist offices. It too dates from the 14th century and survived the Second World War undamaged. Two brass rings in the fencing surrounding the fountain are popular with tourists because of the legends surrounding them - either bringing fertility or good luck, depending on which you believe.
sources.shortName: Nuremberg Sights - 10 Places to See in the City

sources.snippet: The citizens of Nuremberg, clearly, didnâ€™t put much effort into naming the fountain, but I canâ€™t argue with their logic: the fountain is indeed beautiful. But whatâ€™s more important is that it grants wishes â€” all you need to do is turn a small brass ring on the fence three times. When you come up to the fountain, youâ€™ll see people lining up to turn it.
sources.shortName: 38 Things to Do in Nuremberg: a Localâ€™s Guide

sources.snippet: With a knowledgeable local leading the way, youâ€™ll also have the chance to capture the beauty of iconic landmarks like Frauenkirche and SchÃ¶ner Brunnen.
sources.shortName: Capture The Most Photogenic Spots Of Nuremberg With A Local
Discover Beyond | Activity | Explore the Instaworthy Spotsâ€¦

places.name: SchÃ¶ner Brunnen

reviews.text: beautiful city. calm, clean, cozy. we walked after 6 pm, saw the sunset between the houses, enough cafes and pubs, people were resting, walking. want to come back again
Cool sculpture with ornate decoration.  Spire like so looks like it should be on. Cathedral!

Adorned fountain, lovely and small. Has a beautiful love story to the gate! (NÃ¼rnberg has so much history) don't forget to find the brass ring on the gate and spin it for luck! Even had an adorable  furry visitor to it  coming by for their own luck!

places.generalDescription: The Imperial Castle of Nuremberg, also known as Kaiserburg, is a majestic 11th-century castle complex that includes a royal palace and gardens. Perched on a sandstone cliff overlooking the city, it is divided into three parts: the imperial castle Kaiserburg, noble buildings in Burggrafenburg, and other structures to the east in stadtische Burganlage.

sources.snippet: Whenever the emperor of the Holy Roman Empire returned to the Imperial Castle, his arrival would be heralded by a procession, festive music and the ringing of bells. Now, in the Knightâ€™s Hall you can see an animated version of the spectacular scene depicted above the windows. The castle in its current form was built in the 13th century.
sources.shortName: The Top Things To Do And See In Nuremberg

sources.snippet: The medieval castle complex above Nuremberg, known as the Kaiserburg, is a fascinating historical reminder of the city's glories. It actually consists of three different elements of fortification: the old Imperial castle; the Burgrave's castle (the rulers of Nuremberg in the Middle Ages); and the city wall fortifications. The castle grounds are free to visit and the gardens in the old exterior fortifications are well worth a wander.
sources.shortName: Nuremberg Sights - 10 Places to See in the City

sources.snippet: Christkindlesmarkt: Nuremberg's famous Christmas market, Christkindlesmarkt, is one of the oldest and most traditional in Germany. Held annually in the Old Town, it features hundreds of stalls selling handmade ornaments, crafts, and seasonal treats. The festive decorations, twinkling lights, and bustling crowds create a magical atmosphere that is perfect for capturing captivating holiday scenes.
sources.shortName: Top 13 Photo Spots in Nuremberg in 2024

sources.snippet: From the majestic Nuremberg Castle to the quaint Albrecht DÃ¼rer House, these architectural marvels offer endless photo opportunities. However, a local guide knows the ideal time of day and the precise angles that enhance these iconic structures, ensuring your photographs truly capture their grandeur.
sources.shortName: Review Top Nuremberg: Capturing the Most Photogenic Spots with a Local Guide | by Lorafsasexton | Oct, 2024

sources.snippet: The Imperial Castle of Nuremberg (NÃ¼rnberger Burg), is an impressive 351-meter-tall fortification that dominates the Old Town's skyline. One of the most important surviving medieval fortresses in all of Europe, it was once the residence of all legitimate German kings and emperors from 1050 to 1571.
sources.shortName: 19 Top Attractions & Things to Do in Nuremberg

sources.snippet: Rich History: The Imperial Castle is a symbol of Nurembergâ€™s history and power. Explore its ancient walls and learn about the important events that took place here. Capture stunning photos of the castleâ€™s architecture and panoramic views of the city.
sources.shortName: Nuremberg Instagrammable Places Tour

sources.snippet: There are many beautiful churches within the walls, and the Imperial Castle overlooking the area should not be missed. Once at the top you have panoramic views of the city and the castle has large grounds and tours as well.
sources.shortName: A Fall Photo Tour of Nuremberg

sources.snippet: And then it happens only twice a year on a few precious days, in February and October, that the sun sets directly behind the towers of the Imperial Castle. And then you have to hope for perfect weather conditions.
sources.shortName: Nuremberg's Best Sunset

sources.snippet: Nuremberg is the second largest city in Bavaria, with a population of about 520,000. Together with 11 district-free cities and 23 counties, the Nuremberg metropolitan region comprises almost 3.6 million people.
sources.shortName: Sights & Photo Spots in the Old Town (Germany)

sources.snippet: Imperial Castle: The imposing Imperial Castle is one of the city's most famous landmarks and offers an impressive view over Nuremberg.
sources.shortName: Nuremberg Guide | The best photo spots in Nuremberg
5 Days In Nuremberg, Germany - 8 Best Photo Spots
24 Best Things to Do & See in Nuremberg

places.name: Imperial Castle of Nuremberg

reviews.text: It's a bit of a hill climb but well worth it. We didn't get a chance to do that Castle tour, but we climbed up the ramparts and explored a bit. The view from atop The  ramparts is absolutely amazing. Nurnberg in general is a beautiful city and I wish I had had more time there. We were just stopping by on a road trip.

Every time, one can find something unseen before. For a quick ride or precise exploration of a certain part, it's a nice place. And, of course, the view from the top is stunning. Climbing the tower will praise you.

Visitors can explore the grounds and courtyards. A key highlight is climbing the Sinwell Tower for panoramic views of the city. The castle's architecture and exhibits effectively tell the story of its significance.

places.generalDescription: The German Railway Museum Nuremberg is a significant indoor-outdoor museum that showcases the history of rail transport in Germany. It was established in 1899 and features a wide collection of vintage trains, rolling stock, railway equipment, and artifacts from the 19th century to the present day. The museum provides an immersive experience for visitors to explore the technological advancements and historical events that shaped the modern train system.

sources.snippet: The Imperial Castle of Nuremberg (NÃ¼rnberger Burg), is an impressive 351-meter-tall fortification that dominates the Old Town's skyline. One of the most important surviving medieval fortresses in all of Europe, it was once the residence of all legitimate German kings and emperors from 1050 to 1571.
sources.shortName: 19 Top Attractions & Things to Do in Nuremberg

sources.snippet: All aboard for a fascinating journey through the history of trains at the DB Museum. Kids can explore vintage locomotives, play with model trains, and even take a ride on a historic train during special events.
sources.shortName: 5 Days In Nuremberg, Germany - 8 Best Photo Spots

places.name: German Railway Museum Nuremberg

reviews.text:
A Must-Visit for Train Enthusiasts â€“ DB Museum Nuremberg Honest Review

I had a fantastic time exploring the **DB Museum in Nuremberg**, which offers a **rich history of German railways** and an engaging experience for all ages.

### **Location & Accessibility:** â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
The museum is **centrally located** and easy to reach by public transport. It's just a short walk from **Nuremberg's main train station**, making it convenient for visitors.

### **Exhibits & Experience:** â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
The museum covers **over 180 years of railway history**, featuring **original locomotives, interactive displays, and historical artifacts**. Some highlights include:
- **Beautifully restored vintage trains**, including steam engines and royal carriages.
- **A large model railway** showcasing railway operations in a fascinating way.
- **Interactive exhibits** explaining the evolution of railway technology.

### **Family & Kids-Friendly Features:** â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
The **Kinder-Bahnland (Kids' Railway World)** is a fantastic area for children, with **hands-on activities and miniature trains** to keep them engaged.

### **Service & Facilities:** â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
The museum is **well-maintained**, with **clear signage in German and English**. Staff members are friendly and knowledgeable. There's also a **small cafÃ© and a gift shop** with railway-themed souvenirs.

### **Overall Experience:** â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…
A **must-visit for train lovers**, history buffs, and families! Whether you're deeply interested in railway history or just looking for an engaging museum in Nuremberg, **the DB Museum is worth your time**.

Worth it ðŸ’¯!!!
It's really cool for train's fans. People can learn a lot about many kind of train in Germany. They also have break room (pausenraum oder Brotzeit Raumâ€œ.

We will come back again for sure.

Excellent railway museum, which lots to see. Allow at least 2 hours, but you can easily spend 3 hours here. Far more than just trains, as some really interesting models, historical exhibits and even an explanation about how train toilets work!
The App is worth downloading, as it gives additional information in English. Much of the museum has English captions.
Don't forget the separate shed and outside area across the road.

places.generalDescription: Handwerkerhof Nuremberg is a medieval-style shopping area located near the city walls and the railway station. It features small shops that specialize in traditional crafts, offering a unique experience reminiscent of the Middle Ages. Established in 1970 to commemorate Albrecht Durer's 500th birthday, this craftsmen's courtyard was initially intended to be temporary but has become a permanent attraction due to its popularity.

sources.snippet: It is a small area within the Old Town, close to the main train station, with lots of artisanâ€™s shops and cute cafes. If you are looking for a souvenir, here youâ€™ll find Christmas ornaments, ceramics, leather, and wooden toys to name a few. Even if you are not up for shopping, Handwerkerhof is one of the prettiest corners of the Old Town with lots of Medieval houses and is a pleasure to explore.
sources.shortName: 38 Things to Do in Nuremberg: a Localâ€™s Guide

sources.snippet: Passing into the walled city, on the left is the Handwerkerhof â€“ a kind of recreated medieval village filled with artisans selling all manner of goods. This strictly made-for-tourists two-lane village is cute to walk through, but Iâ€™ve never actually shopped here.
sources.shortName: 15 Inspiring Photos of Nuremberg, Germany

sources.snippet: You can witness craftsmen at work in the famous Handwerkerhof while exploring the photogenic spots of Nuremberg with a local guide. The Handwerkerhof is a local market in a medieval setting, where traditional crafts and artisanal skills are showcased.
sources.shortName: Capture The Most Photogenic Spots Of Nuremberg With A Local
Discover Nurembergâ€™s most Photogenic Spots with a Local - Nuremberg, Germany

places.name: Handwerkerhof Nuremberg

reviews.text: Very nice small place which really gives you an insight on medieval times.

At the Nuremberg Handicraft Village, I had the chance to see beautifully crafted handmade items, including leather goods, candles, and clothing-all with a distinctly European charm. The atmosphere itself felt authentically European, making the experience even more enjoyable.

There are restaurants and cafÃ©s on-site, so keep that in mind if you plan to take a break during your visit. I was particularly impressed by the people there and received exceptionally friendly service.

However, the prices? Absolutely insane

I absolutely adore this place. It is literally the first thing you see after you exit the main train station and it is definitely worth your time. Plenty of tiny shops and cafes, you will most likely find something to peak your interest.

places.generalDescription: The Frauenkirche, also known as the Church of Lady, is a Gothic Catholic church in Nuremberg that dates back to 1362. It is one of the most recognizable churches in the city and serves as a backdrop for the famous Christmas Market. The church's pinnacled brick Gothic facade stands out in the Hauptmarkt, Nuremberg's main square. During Christmas, the festive stalls surrounding the church create a magical atmosphere reminiscent of a European holiday movie.

sources.snippet: Spice up your socials as you capture the picturesque Kaiserburg NÃ¼rnberg to the visually stunning Frauenkirche and immerse yourself into Nurembergâ€™s everyday charm as your Local guides you through its lively neighbourhoods. From eye-catching scenery to vibrant local encounters, this experience with a Local is a definite must-do for those seeking a personal and authentic discovery of Nuremberg. â€¢ Navigate Nuremberg's most Insta-worthy spots with a Local.
sources.shortName: Discover Beyond | Activity | Explore the Instaworthy Spotsâ€¦

sources.snippet: While we are at the market square, letâ€™s cover some of the most popular things to do in Nuremberg. The Church of Our Lady, located on the eastern side of the square, is one of the three main churches in the city. Every year, from the balcony of this church the Christkind, a blonde angelic girl who is believed to bring presents for holidays in many European countries, reads a prologue, thus signifying the opening of the Christmas market.
sources.shortName: 38 Things to Do in Nuremberg: a Localâ€™s Guide

sources.snippet: Christkindlesmarkt: Nuremberg's famous Christmas market, Christkindlesmarkt, is one of the oldest and most traditional in Germany. Held annually in the Old Town, it features hundreds of stalls selling handmade ornaments, crafts, and seasonal treats. The festive decorations, twinkling lights, and bustling crowds create a magical atmosphere that is perfect for capturing captivating holiday scenes.
sources.shortName: Top 13 Photo Spots in Nuremberg in 2024

sources.snippet: The Frauenkirche (' Church of Our Lady') is a Catholic church located on the main square of Nuremberg old town. The famous Nuremberg Christmas Market takes place in front of the church and the 'Christkind' opens the market from the entrance. A clock on the church facade has figures which move in a display at midday.
sources.shortName: Nuremberg Sights - 10 Places to See in the City

sources.snippet: Of course the most famous church in Nuremberg is the Church of Our Lady (the Frauenkirche). From the balcony every December, a blond teenage girl opens the Nuremberg Christmas Markets for the year. This spectacle is worth a very cold wintry visit to see Germanyâ€™s top Christkindlmarkt.
sources.shortName: 15 Inspiring Photos of Nuremberg, Germany

sources.snippet: Itâ€™s that GIANT, multi-tiered, beautiful, 14th century, Gothic church dominating the whole square. Tip: Be there at noon to watch the famous Nuremberg Glockenspiel Show. Inside this Christian church, you might be surprised to see a Star of David.
sources.shortName: The Only List You'll Need Of Things To Do In Nuremberg

sources.snippet: A photograph of the Frauenkirche isnâ€™t just a photograph; itâ€™s a reflection of the cityâ€™s religious significance. A picture of the historic market square evokes the cityâ€™s bustling trade and commerce through the centuries.
sources.shortName: Review Top Nuremberg: Capturing the Most Photogenic Spots with a Local Guide | by Lorafsasexton | Oct, 2024

sources.snippet: With a knowledgeable local leading the way, youâ€™ll also have the chance to capture the beauty of iconic landmarks like Frauenkirche and SchÃ¶ner Brunnen.
sources.shortName: Capture The Most Photogenic Spots Of Nuremberg With A Local

sources.snippet: Frauenkirche NÃ¼rnberg is THE most iconic place in town, come with me to discover the history of this gothic church!
sources.shortName: Discover Nurembergâ€™s most Photogenic Spots with a Local - Nuremberg, Germany
19 Top Attractions & Things to Do in Nuremberg

places.name: Frauenkirche

reviews.text: The Frauenkirche in Nuremberg is a stunning 14th-century Brick Gothic church located on the Hauptmarkt. It's best known for its intricate mechanical clock, the MÃ¤nnleinlaufen, which puts on a daily spectacle at noon, drawing crowds to witness its historical parade of figures. The church's interior offers a peaceful atmosphere and beautiful historical details.

It is the church on main city market square, so it's guaranteed a lot of attention. Built by 1362 on the site of destroyed synagogue on the order of Emperor Charles IV , this church suffered severe damage in Allied bombing raids in 1945. However iconic facade with mechanical clock has survived and rest of the church was restored by 1955. This clock's performance at 12pm draws daily stream of visitors to Hauptmarkt. That's probably also my most vivid recollection from city visit.
gothic church from 1358, preserved most of the sculptures from the medieval ages. the watch play is great and the facade is amazing and it is itself a trip into history.

places.generalDescription: St. Lorenz Church is a restored Gothic church in Nuremberg, Germany, which suffered severe damage during World War II but was rebuilt. The church features impressive interior artwork and a large organ. Visitors can explore the Nuremberg Old Town with a local expert guide to see four beautiful medieval churches, including St. Lorenz Church, and learn about their unique historical stories.

sources.snippet: I always find myself taking a pause in the square in front of St. Lorenz Church. This square is always filled with market stalls and dozens of locals milling about waiting for friends. While other churches in Nuremberg draw the visitors, St. Lorenz towers over the daily life in Nuremberg.
sources.shortName: 15 Inspiring Photos of Nuremberg, Germany

sources.snippet: From the majestic St. Lorenz Church to the picturesque Rathausplatz, this tour promises to be a dream come true for avid photographers and social media enthusiasts.
sources.shortName: Nuremberg Instagrammable Places Tour
Discover Nurembergâ€™s most Photogenic Spots with a Local - Nuremberg, Germany
19 Top Attractions & Things to Do in Nuremberg
9 Instagram-mable spots & (free) things to do in Nuremberg

places.name: St. Lorenz

reviews.text: Absolutely beautiful. Historical cathedrals with their spires, intricate side chapels, and impossibly high ceilings are a must-see for me. I just can't imagine praying in one... I'd be too distracted!

St. Lawrence is the Cathedral Church of Nuremberg with twin bell towers. It is located in Alstadt very center surrounded with many market stalls. Church is free to enter with tall classic Gothic arches inside with very few stained glass.
WWII devastations miraculously spared the twin towers which only endured minor damages

St. Lorenz is one of NÃ¼rnberg's most breathtaking landmarks, showcasing stunning Gothic architecture that leaves a lasting impression. As you step inside, the grandeur of the interior is immediately striking, with its high vaulted ceilings, intricate stained glass windows, and masterfully crafted details.

The sense of history in St. Lorenz is palpable-it's a true gem of the city, and a must-visit for anyone who appreciates art, architecture, and spiritual heritage. The organ and acoustics make it a special experience for anyone attending a service or concert. It's also centrally located, making it easy to visit while exploring the rest of the city.

Whether you're a history enthusiast, a lover of beautiful architecture, or just someone seeking a moment of quiet reflection, St. Lorenz is a place that should not be missed. It perfectly embodies the rich history and culture of NÃ¼rnberg.

places.generalDescription: Museum Bridge, a sandstone arch bridge, spans the Pegnitz river and offers picturesque views of Nuremberg. It replaced a 13th-century bridge destroyed during World War II and seamlessly blends with the surrounding architecture. From the bridge, visitors can admire the Hospital of the Holy Spirit, once housing the crown of the Holy Roman Emperor, and catch sight of Fleischbrucke, said to be inspired by Venice's Rialto Bridge.

sources.snippet: This bridge is on the Pegnitz river looking over to the Hospital of the Holy Spirit (which is now a restaurant) . The hospital holds importance because it actually held the crown of the Holy Roman Emperor at one time. Turn the other direction and look over at the FleischbrÃ¼cke, which many people say gets its inspiration from the famous Rialto Bridge in Venice.
sources.shortName: The Only List You'll Need Of Things To Do In Nuremberg

places.name: MuseumsbrÃ¼cke

reviews.text: A nice stone bridge that has really nice views on both sides. You can take really nice pics here. Most likely there will be shops there so it might be hard to find an empty place to take pics from
It is a beautiful bridge, free to walk. Links the 2 parts of the old city centre. During the day it often hosts a fruit and vegetables market.

stone bridge built on the river where you can see from both sides some medieval buildings and restaurants. fortified in the 1700's after the flood destroyed many previous wooden bridges in the site. it connects the city market to Lorenzplatz.

places.generalDescription: The Albrecht DÃ¼rer House in Nuremberg is a must-visit for art enthusiasts and history buffs. This timbered Gothic house survived WWII bombing and now houses original etchings and woodcuts by the renowned German Renaissance artist, Albrecht DÃ¼rer. The museum offers a glimpse into DÃ¼rer's life, featuring a recreated studio and print shop, as well as a gallery showcasing both replica and original works.

sources.snippet: A recently restored building, the house of the Renaissance artist Albrecht DÃ¼rer is now a museum dedicated to the artistâ€™s life and work. His works are currently on display in every corner of the world, even on chocolate bars and currency. DÃ¼rer is widely regarded as having changed the course of art history in terms of his mania for perfection and bringing technology to the medium of engraving.
sources.shortName: The Top Things To Do And See In Nuremberg

sources.snippet: From the majestic Nuremberg Castle to the quaint Albrecht DÃ¼rer House, these architectural marvels offer endless photo opportunities. However, a local guide knows the ideal time of day and the precise angles that enhance these iconic structures, ensuring your photographs truly capture their grandeur.
sources.shortName: Review Top Nuremberg: Capturing the Most Photogenic Spots with a Local Guide | by Lorafsasexton | Oct, 2024

sources.snippet: One of the most prominent German painters, Albrecht DÃ¼rer, was born in Nuremberg. He lived and worked in a five-storied half-timbered house, located not far from the Imperial Castle, from 1509 until his death in 1528. Today, you can visit a museum dedicated to DÃ¼rerâ€™s life and work inside the house.
sources.shortName: 38 Things to Do in Nuremberg: a Localâ€™s Guide

sources.snippet: There are also many historical museums such as the German National Museum, Albrecht DrÃ¼rerâ€™s House, and the Nazi Documentation Center. Nuremberg is also a city with a long history in toy making that dates back to the middle ages, and as such has a Toy Museum.
sources.shortName: A Fall Photo Tour of Nuremberg

sources.snippet: Albrecht DÃ¼rerâ€™s House, the former residence of the renowned artist, is a must-visit destination for art enthusiasts. It offers a glimpse into the life and works of this influential figure in German Renaissance art.
sources.shortName: Capture The Most Photogenic Spots Of Nuremberg With A Local

sources.snippet: Albrecht DÃ¼rer House: The former home of the famous painter Albrecht DÃ¼rer is now a museum and attracts art lovers from all over the world.
sources.shortName: Nuremberg Guide | The best photo spots in Nuremberg
24 Best Things to Do & See in Nuremberg
15 Inspiring Photos of Nuremberg, Germany

places.name: Museums Nuremberg - Albrecht DÃ¼rer House

reviews.text: I highly recommend the guided tour! The lady who portrayed Agnes, Albrecht DÃ¼rer's wife, did a wonderful job-she gave us a deeper understanding of his life and what inspired him. We really enjoyed the experience!

A little gem in the old town of Nurnberg. Very organized exposition, with a walk through the house and a new section with a gallery of some of his works. Also, the top floor of the house has some of Durer's original sketches. There's an audio guide in different languages that comes with the entry ticket. Also, a free wardrobe is provided where you can leave your backpack while in the museum.
Highly recommended.

I had a nice experience walking through the old house, though most of it is not original. The exhibitions nicely explained the life and works of Albrecht DÃ¼rer, and also how the printing press worked and how paint was made back then. There were also demonstrations. The original printworks were visible at the top floor. There were steep stairs, so I'm not sure how accessible the museum is.

places.generalDescription: St. Sebald Church, also known as Sebalduskirche NÃ¼rnberg, is a stunning Gothic-era Lutheran church in Nuremberg. The church features beautiful stained glass windows, intricate paintings, and an impressive pipe organ. Built from 1225-73, the Protestant St.

sources.snippet: St Sebald is one of the patron saints of Nuremberg and the church dedicated to him in the Sebald area of the centre of the city houses his tomb. Construction started on the Church of St Sebald, which was a place of pilgrimage in the Middle Ages, in the 13th century (although the original church was dedicated to St Peter). Along with the Lorenzkirche, the church is one of the major Protestant churches in Franconia.
sources.shortName: Nuremberg Sights - 10 Places to See in the City

sources.snippet: The last of the three most prominent churches in Nuremberg is Saint Sebald Church. All three are located within minutes from one another. The church is named after the patron saint of Nuremberg and houses the shrine of Saint Sebald.
sources.shortName: 38 Things to Do in Nuremberg: a Localâ€™s Guide
15 Inspiring Photos of Nuremberg, Germany

places.name: St. Sebald - Sebalduskirche NÃ¼rnberg

reviews.text:
A few weeks ago, I was lucky enough to discover and explore this great church with #Littlefeet. On the occasion of a choir trip to Nuremberg, #Littlefeet and its choir were able to give a small concert in the Sebalduskirche or St. Sebaldkirche during a prayer service together with the Nuremberg Youth Choir.

Really impressive!

This church is a masterpiece! We were even allowed into the choir of angels and the choir sang the Our Father high up there, so that the visitors down in the nave turned around in amazement and delight ...

Before the choir sang a few songs in the nave in front of the altar, we were able to experience the impressive organ. And for those who missed it: Outside next to the entrance is a plaque stating that Johann Pachelbel worked here as an organist from 1695 to 1706.

It was a wonderful time in one of the most beautiful churches in Bavaria. The wonderfully painted windows, the altar and the tomb of St. Sebald in particular impress even people who have nothing to do with church culture or the Christian faith.

Thanks for this wonderful experience to everyone who made it possible. Thumbs up!

Absolutely stunning; hands down one of the most beautiful churches I've visited in Europe. The twin spires dominate the skyline, but it's the details that stay with you: Romanesque roots blending seamlessly with soaring Gothic architecture, the intricate stone carvings over the portals, and the rich play of light through centuries-old stained glass.

Inside, the space is breathtaking. The high vaulted ceilings lift your eyes upward, while the elaborate tomb of St. Sebald, crafted in dark bronze with remarkable detail, anchors the interior with reverence. Each chapel holds its own story, from altarpieces to frescoes, giving you a sense of both faith and history woven together.

What struck me most was the atmosphere; it feels both grand and intimate, a living part of Nuremberg's heritage rather than just a monument. This is a place to linger, to take in the artistry, and to appreciate how much care and devotion went into creating and preserving it over the centuries.

The Sebalduskirche (St. Sebald's Church) in Nuremberg is the oldest parish church in the city and is dedicated to St. Sebald, the patron saint of Nuremberg. It is located in the northern part of the old town, on the Albrecht-DÃ¼rer-Platz, next to the Old Town Hall. The church is one of the three main churches in Nuremberg, along with the Frauenkirche and the Lawrence Church.

Highlights:

Oldest parish church:

Dedicated to St. Sebald, a missionary and hermit who lived in the area around Nuremberg.

Architecture:

Built in late Romanesque style with two choirs.

Historical significance:

Considered an important Protestant church after the Reformation.

Relics:

The church contains the tomb of Saint Sebald, made by Peter Fischer in the 16th century.

Windows:

The church is famous for its stained glass windows depicting biblical scenes.

Location:

Located next to the castle and the old town hall.

places.generalDescription: The New Museum - Nuremberg State Museum of Art and Design, opened in 2000, is housed in a striking building with a curved glass facade. The museum's 7,800 square meters of exhibition space are dedicated to contemporary art and design. The ground floor features an impressive design collection showcasing international design from 1945 to the present day. Visitors can explore visionary trends and highlights from different movements displayed on three parallel time axes, providing diverse perspectives.

sources.snippet: Neues Museum, literally translated as New Museum, is another favorite of mine. The building which was constructed specifically for the museum is a paradox of sorts. Its enormous glass facade stretches for 100 meters, yet it is well hidden within the Old Town.
sources.shortName: 38 Things to Do in Nuremberg: a Localâ€™s Guide
24 Best Things to Do & See in Nuremberg

places.name: New Museum - Nuremberg State Museum of Art and Design

reviews.text: World-class museum in a building with modern architecture. Well-curated and perfect for a 2-hour visit.

Limited collection featuring art pieces that do not provoke much thought in a huge modern space. One of the exhibition rooms at level 3 is closed. Spent more time at the museum shop than the museum itself.

Not sure about this place, the architecture definitely is interesting in mixing the old with the new and reflecting the city walls in its all glass outside but the interior is rather empty and what is there put on display is ... not that much and not that interesting. I admit I am hardly a fan of modern art but even so I expected a bit more "meat" let's say

places.generalDescription: The City Museum in Fembo House is a restored 1500s former merchant's residence that offers free admission to various attractions and savings on guided tours. It is the only late Renaissance merchant's house in Nuremberg and the sole historical building in the Old Town to survive World War II bombings. Visitors can explore its grand historic rooms, including carved wooden furniture, ceiling paintings, and a traditional kitchen recreation.

sources.shortName: 24 Best Things to Do & See in Nuremberg

places.name: Stadtmuseum im Fembo-Haus

reviews.text: The clerk apologized for not having any more English listening devices; as it turned out, we didn't need them.  The museum spoke for itself, containing not only artistic treasures from Nuremberg's past but the house itself, being one of the only similar mansions to survive the wartime bombing, displayed all manner of ancient and clever German craftsmanship.  Indeed, the Fembo mansion is the most important artifact of the museum in my opinion.  The museum also does a great job of showing before, during, and after photographs of the wartime bombing.  The museum is centrally located, easy to find, and affords wonderful views of the city as it is on a hill near the fortress.  We hit the museum before we did anything else in Nuremberg, and it turned out to be a great strategy as our visit to the museum gave us a whole other level of understanding the city as we explored it.  Friends and my own research had alerted me to the quality of this museum, and I can confirm that even the most jaded of my party agreed that it was a highlight of our trip.

No visit to the mediaeval city of Nuremberg would be complete without experiencing the  Stadtsmuseum in Fembo House- a grand old edifice just up from the Hauptmarket...After receiving a hearty welcome and introduction to the museum my tour began with a short lift ride to the fourth floor offering outstanding vistas of old town  Nuremberg....One highlight of the top floor was a computer generated reconstruction of the beautiful Jewish Synagogue brutally demolished in 1938... There are also two faithfully carved models from middle ages Nuremberg... Descending the ornately carved wooden staircase brings you to a veritable managerie of Nuremberg artwork , prints , weapons and unique curios with the tour finally ending  at the groundfloor exhibit of graffic , confronting photographs of heavily bombed Nuremberg in 1945...A visit to the Stadtsmuseum is certainly a multifaceted sojourn into the fascinating and tumultuous history of one of Germany's grandest old cities.

Well designed and presented museum about Nuremberg.

If you visit one of the  5 other partipating museums the same day you can visit it for 3 extra euros to get a day pass.

places.generalDescription: The Mittelalterliche LochgefÃ¤ngnisse, located beneath the city hall, is a 14th-century dungeon with 12 prison cells and a torture chamber. It is one of the largest medieval dungeons in the world that has been preserved. Visitors can explore this historical site through guided tours, gaining insights into the justice system and experiencing the dark and cramped conditions prisoners endured from the 14th to the 19th centuries.

sources.snippet: Just a few steps away from the main market square, vaulted cellars below the splendid city hall built in Nuremberg's golden age accommodate the mediaeval dungeons. They were established as early as the 14th century and were not prisons as we know them today, but were used mainly for prisoners awaiting trial and for convicted criminals awaiting execution of their judgement.
sources.shortName: Nuremberg - Unique Spots

places.name: Mittelalterliche LochgefÃ¤ngnisse

reviews.text:
A fascinating tour of the dungeons under the Rathaus in Nuremberg. We found the English speaking tour excellent with our guide's English really good and an appropriate sense of humour. There are a fair amount of stairs as the tour goes underground.

Book ahead - the maximum is 20 for each tour and don't be late - the tour starts at the time stated. It is suitable for all ages and there's no people jumping out and going boo!

I recommend purchasing your ticket online as it is impossible to buy it on the spot. Although there is a qr code that you can scan at the meeting point (on a small plaque on the wall of the old city hall, very inconspicuous), each tour is limited to 20 people so advance booking is still the best option. There is only one English guided tour at 18.00. If you end up in a German guided tour and don't understand much German, tell your guide at the beginning - - they will give you an audio guide. It doesn't give as much as information as the guide themselves, but at least you won't be completely lost.
The tour takes about 50 minutes during which one goes through a series of dungeon chambers with the guide. It is a very cool place; one can learn quite some history down there.

I'm torn because what you get to see is very cool and our tour guide was great (we did the English speaking tour)... BUT the rudeness of the other staff made it really awkward. It is ABUNDANTLY clear they do not like English speaking tourists. They need to get other jobs cause like why work in a tourist spot if you hate tourists? Make it make sense.

places.generalDescription: Ehekarussell, also known as the 'Marriage Merry-Go-Round,' is a controversial bronze fountain located near the White Tower in Nuremberg. Created by sculptor Jurgen Weber in 1984, this large and intriguing sculpture depicts various stages of courtship and marriage over six scenes, based on a poem by 16th-century poet Hans Sachs.

sources.snippet: The grotesque bronze fountain right by the WeiÃŸer Turm tower looks disturbing as it is, with half-naked men and women, bizarre animals, and skeletons strangling each other, but once you learn that the sculptures represent the stages of marriage, it becomes outright horrifying. Or funny, depends on how you look at it.
sources.shortName: 38 Things to Do in Nuremberg: a Localâ€™s Guide
Discover Beyond | Activity | Explore the Instaworthy Spotsâ€¦

places.name: Ehekarussell

reviews.text:
Inside the medieval walls of the city, between past and present, the â€œMarriage-Merry-Go-Round" fountain  from 1984, created in 4 years by JÃ¼rgen Weber.
Inspired by the ironic  medieval poem of  Hans  Sachs  â€œDas bittersÃ¼ÃŸe ehlich Lebenâ€, narrating the joys and sorrows of life as a couple that can be summed up in these stanzas : â€œShe is my virtue and my vice, She is my wound and also my plasterâ€.
One of the most fascinating fountains I've seen in a long time. Pitty not more info is displayed about its origin.

Walk around this beautiful bronze fountain to follow a couple's whole life, from the sweetness of first romance to the messiness of conflict, and finally, a haunting skeletal dance. The brutal honesty and brilliant level of detail make it a truly one-of-a-kind sight.

places.generalDescription: Sinwell Tower, part of the Imperial Castle in Nuremberg, is a cylindrical keep built in the 13th century. Although currently closed for restoration, it offers panoramic views of the city from its top after climbing around 100 stairs. The tower's historical significance and architectural evolution are explained through sketches and texts at the summit.

sources.shortName: A Fall Photo Tour of Nuremberg

places.name: Sinwellturm

reviews.text:
A good 1 day visit to the town of Nuremberg.
For the castle, if you are not into history, don't buy the combined ticket which includes a museum (9 euros) but only take the sinwell and deepwell combined ticket which is 4 euros for the adult.

For sinwell, only 30 people allowed and be ready climb 100+ stairs for a top view of the city.

For deep well, there is a guided tour duration 10 minutes. It happens every 30 mins (9:30 am to 5:30 pm) picture attached.

The chapel is not much to see and museum doesn't make sense for people who are not into history.

Being from Asia, The history museum wasn't something that caught my attention.

The best point for a 360 degrees view of the old town. Take care, there isn't an elevator, you have to climb some pretty steep and narrow staircase. There's a small fee to pay for the access that also grants you the entry to the museum and to the "deep well".

Sinwellturm rises powerfully within the Kaiserburg complex, its perfectly round form making it one of the most striking towers in Nuremberg. Built in the late 13th century, it was both a symbol of imperial authority and a defensive watchtower. Climbing the narrow wooden spiral staircase is an experience in itself, and once at the top, the reward is a sweeping 360Â° view across the city's rooftops, churches, and beyond to the Franconian countryside. From here, the scale of Nuremberg truly comes into focus. Inside, displays include historic drawings and photographs showing the destruction of the Old Town during World War II, which adds a poignant layer to the panorama before you. Both historically significant and visually unforgettable, this tower is one of the highlights of visiting the castle.
